column1: Athletic Club Ajaccio (Corsican: Athletic Club Aiacciu)
column2: commonly referred to as AC Ajaccio
column4: is a French association football club based in the city of Ajaccio on the island of Corsica. The club was founded in 1910 and plays in Ligue 2. The club president is Christian Leca
column5: and the first-team is coached by manager Olivier Pantaloni
column6: following the sacking of Christian Bracconi in October 2014. Ajaccio play their home matches at the Stade François Coty and are rivals with fellow Corsican club Bastia
column7: with whom they contest the Corsica derby (Derby Corse).

column2: it is agreed that Ajaccio began playing in 1909–10. Their adopted colors are red and white stripes. Though they used to play in what was previously utilised as a sand dump
column3: they decided to move to another
column5: safer stadium upon the insistence of Jean Lluis
column6: father-in-law of club president Louis Baretti. The new stadium that was chosen held 5
column7: 000 spectators and was in use until 1969.

column1: AC Ajaccio were elected Corsican champions on eight occasions
column9: and are one of three big "island" teams
column10: along with Gazélec Ajaccio and Bastia
column11: the competition between the three being kept no secret. Spectators during the 1946 Corsican Cup final
column12: held between A.C.A. and Sporting Bastia were handed umbrellas to shield themselves from the violence. Upon refusal of a penalty which would have been awarded to ACA
column14: who used umbrellas both to cause and shield themselves from violence. This final was abandoned and replayed much later.

column1: A.C.A. became a professional team in 1965 thanks to the ambitious efforts of the club's leaders. They initially adopted the symbol of the polar bear
column2: but this has since been dropped in favour of a more stylised logo that uses a part of the Corsican flag.
the team became the first Corsican club to play in France's top division. They were most recently in Ligue 1 in the 2013–14 season
column3: when they were relegated after finishing in last place
column4: following a spell of three seasons in the top flight; the drop was confirmed with defeat at neighbours Bastia.In November 2014
column5: Olivier Pantaloni returned for a third spell as manager. His team came third in 2017–18
column7: where they beat Le Havre in a semi-final marred by violence on and off the pitch
column8: before losing the final to Toulouse. The club were denied promotion in 2019–20 when the season was curtailed with ten games remaining due to the coronavirus pandemic; Ajaccio were one point off the top two
column9: who were the only ones to go up as the play-offs could not contested.
